metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Trademark infringement is a key issue in the case, with the respondent admitting to the plaintiffs' proprietary rights in the 'SAKARNI' trademark.
The plaintiffs' copyright in the artistic features of their packaging pouches, labels, and other materials is acknowledged by the respondent.
The prior use of the 'SAKARNI' trademark by the plaintiffs is recognized, giving them priority over the respondent.
The respondent's undertaking not to commit any acts of infringement or passing off by using similar trademarks or marks is a crucial aspect of the settlement.
The protection of the plaintiffs' registered trademarks and labels, including their scripts, fonts, and get-ups, is ensured through the respondent's admissions and undertakings.
The respondent's admission of the plaintiffs' ownership of copyright in artistic works related to the 'SAKARNI' trademark is significant.
The settlement agreement's provision for the respondent not to reproduce or adapt the artistic features of the plaintiffs' packaging material without permission is essential.
The registration of the plaintiffs' pending trademark and copyright applications is not to be objected to by the respondent, according to the settlement.
The prevention of unfair competition through the use of deceptively similar marks or names is a key objective of the settlement agreement.

The enforcement of intellectual property rights, including trademarks and copyrights, is a critical aspect of the case, with the court's mediation and conciliation process facilitating a settlement between the parties.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr. vs. Rishabh Bansal & Anr.**

**Background:**
The case involves a trademark and copyright dispute between Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr. (Plaintiffs/Petitioners) and Rishabh Bansal & Anr. (Respondents/Defendant) in the High Court of Delhi. The dispute centered around the trademark "SAKARNI" used by the Plaintiffs for goods falling under Class 19 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Legal Issues:**

1. **Trademark Infringement:** The Plaintiffs alleged that the Respondents had infringed their trademark "SAKARNI" by using a similar mark "SATKARMI" for similar goods.
2. **Copyright Infringement:** The Plaintiffs also alleged that the Respondents had infringed their copyright in the artistic features of their packaging pouches, labels, and other materials.
3. **Passing Off:** The Plaintiffs claimed that the Respondents' use of the similar mark "SATKARMI" was an attempt to pass off their goods as those of the Plaintiffs.

**Arguments:**

* The Plaintiffs argued that they were the original and registered proprietors of the trademark "SAKARNI" and had been using it since before the Respondents.
* The Respondents argued that their use of the mark "SATKARMI" was not an infringement of the Plaintiffs' trademark, as it was distinct and not likely to cause confusion.

**Settlement Agreement:**
Before the court could rule on the matter, the parties entered into a settlement agreement on March 14, 2023, under the aegis of the Delhi High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre. The terms of the settlement agreement were as follows:

* The Respondents admitted that the Plaintiffs were the original and registered proprietors of the trademark "SAKARNI" and acknowledged their proprietary rights.
* The Respondents acknowledged the Plaintiffs' copyright in the artistic features of their packaging pouches, labels, and other materials.
* The Respondents undertook not to commit any act of infringement or passing off by using the mark "SATKARMI" or any other mark similar to the Plaintiffs' trademarks.
* The Respondents agreed to withdraw their application for registration of the mark "SATKARMI" and not to file any future applications for similar marks.

**Court Findings and Decision:**
The High Court of Delhi, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, accepted the settlement agreement and disposed of the case. The court found that the settlement agreement had resolved all the disputes between the parties and that the Respondents had acknowledged the Plaintiffs' proprietary rights in the trademark "SAKARNI" and their copyright in the artistic features of their packaging materials. The court ordered the Respondents to comply with the terms of the settlement agreement, including withdrawing their application for registration of the mark "SATKARMI" and not using any similar marks in the future.

**Conclusion:**
The case highlights the importance of settlement agreements in resolving intellectual property disputes. The settlement agreement in this case allowed the parties to avoid a lengthy and costly trial, while also ensuring that the Plaintiffs' proprietary rights in their trademark and copyright were protected. The court's acceptance of the settlement agreement and its order for the Respondents to comply with its terms demonstrate the court's commitment to upholding intellectual property rights and preventing infringement and passing off.

The Disputes between the parties stand settled, vide Settlement

“a.

Plaintiffs/Petitioners are original and registered proprietor of the 
trademark/label 
'SAKARNI 
PLASTER/SAKARNI 
WALL 
GUARD/SAKARNI’ in respect of the goods falling in class 19 of

The Respondent no. 1/Defendant also admits and 
acknowledges the Plaintiffs/Petitioners' Copyright in the artistic 
features of the packaging pouches, labels including their distinctive 
scripts, fonts, positions and placing of features, their respective get 
ups, lay outs, combination of colours and arrangements of general 
and descriptive materials in respect of goods falling in class 19. 
 
c.

trademark/label 
'SAKARNI 
PLASTER/SAKARNI 
WALL 
GUARD/SAKARNI’ for the goods falling in class 19. 
 
d.

Plaintiffs/Petitioners to be the owner of Copyright in the artistic 
works 
as 
involved 
in 
the 
trademark/label 
'SAKARNI  
PLASTER/SAKARNI WALL GUARD/SAKARNl' and the 
Respondent no. 1/Defendant shall not have any objection with 
respect to the registration of the pending trademarks and copyright 
applications of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners in any manner whatsoever. 
 
e. 
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant undertakes before this 
Hon'ble Court not to commit any act of infringement and/or 
passing off by the use of the trade mark/device SATKARMI/ 
/SAKARNI and/or any other mark/name which is 
identical and/or deceptively similar to the Plaintiffs/Petitioners 
registered trademarks/labels in any manner whatsoever. 
 
f.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant undertakes before this 
Hon'ble Court not to use the scripts, fonts, positions and placement 
of any features, get ups, lay outs, combination of colours and 
arrangement as are or is identical or deceptively similar to the 
features, get ups, lay-outs, positions and placement or combination 
of colours of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners' pouches/packaging material 
in respect of and in relation to the product P.O.P etc. 
 
g.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant undertakes before this 
Hon'ble Court not to reproduce and/or to make any adaptation of 
any of the artistic features of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners' 
pouches/packaging material including get up, lay out, arrangement 
and/or combination of colours constituting infringement of 
plaintiffs/petitioners' copyright herein including the works as are 
subject matter of copyright registration. 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:11.04.2023
15:25:22
Signature Not Verified

Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:2449 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 3 of 5 
 
 
h. That Respondent no. 1/Defendant further undertakes this 
Hon'ble Court to withdraw the application/registration of the 
impugned mark/device SATKARMI bearing no. 3564551 in Class 
19 within two weeks from the date of the execution of the present 
settlement.  That the Respondent no. 1/Defendant further 
undertakes that there is no application pending before the Registrar 
of Trade Marks or any other authority filed by the 
Defendant/Respondent No. 1 bearing the trademark/device 
“SATKARMI/ 
/SAKARNI” and even in future also the 
respondent no. 1/defendant shall not file any such application for 
the registration which may be similar or identical to the 
Plaintiffs/Petitioners' trademark/label/artistic work/trade dress. In 
view of the said undertaking by the Respondent no. 1/Defendant, 
the plaintiffs/petitioners agree to withdraw the rectification petition 
C.O. (Comm. IPD-TM) No. 752/2022. 
 
i.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant undertakes to this Hon'ble 
Court to recall all the marketing, promotional and advertising 
materials that bear or incorporate the mark “SATKARMI/ 
/SAKARNI” or any other mark similar to the 
Plaintiffs/Petitioners' "SAKARNI PLASTER/SAKARNI WALL 
GUARD/SAKARNI" mark, which have been distributed, sold or 
shipped before entering into the present settlement. 
 
j.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant undertakes before this 
Hon'ble Court that he will destroy all the blocks, dies, screens, 
works, wrappers and any other material in which the impugned 
mark or infringing trade dress or copyright within fifteen days 
from the date of the order passed by this Hon'ble Court. 
 
k.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant further undertakes to this 
Hon'ble Court that he will not either directly or indirectly, or 
through any of its entity apply or encourage others directly or 
indirectly for the registration of any trade mark/trade name 
“SATKARMI/
/SAKARNI” or any word/mark deceptively 
similar to the trademark "SAKARNI PLASTER/SAKARNI 
WALL GUARD/SAKARNI" of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners. 
 
1.  
That the Respondent no. 1/Defendant has already paid a 
sum of Rs. 1,25,000/- by way of two transactions through UPI 
aggregating the settlement amount being Rs. 1,25,000/- to the 
plaintiffs towards token damages in the Bank Account of the 
Plaintiff No. 1/Petitioner No.l's Firm i.e. Jai Durga Plaster 
Industries receipt whereof duly acknowledged. 
 
m. 
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant further agrees to pay the 
plaintiffs/petitioners without any demur or protest a sum of INR 
25,00,000/- (Twenty Five Lakhs Only) in the event of the 
occurrence of any default/breach by them of any condition set forth 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI

15:25:22

herein above provided that such breach/default arises out of the 
act(s) which are directly within the power and control of the 
Respondent no. 1/Defendant; 
 
n.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant has no objection if a 
decree of perpetual injunction is passed by this Hon'ble Court in 
favour of the plaintiffs according to the prayer clause of the 
paragraph 32 (a)&(b) of the plaint in CS (Comm.) No. 48 of 2023 
along with terms and conditions of the present settlement. 
 
o.  
The parties have gone through the terms and conditions 
herein and confirm and verify the same to be correct and that they 
put their signatures hereunder without any threat, coercion, 
pressure, or undue influence from any quarter and both sides agree 
to abide by the terms and conditions herein. 
 
p.  
The Parties have gone through this present Settlement 
Agreement and have understood the same and have no objections 
to the present terms and conditions. The parties also understand 
that bleach of the terms and conditions of this Settlement 
Agreement shall invite lawful action for contempt of court against 
them by the other party in the concerned Court 
 
q.  
That the Parties undertake before the Hon'ble Court to 
abide by the terms and conditions set out in the agreement and not 
to dispute the same hereinafter in future. 
 
r.  
The parties agree that they shall appear before the Hon'ble 
court during the hearing to make their statements in terms of the 
present settlement agreement.” 
 
2. 
Learned Counsel are present on behalf of their respective 
parties.  They undertake to abide by the aforesaid terms of settlement. 
 
3. 
As such, nothing survives for adjudication in the suit as well as 
the rectification petition.  Rectification petition stands disposed of and 
the suit stands decreed in terms of the aforesaid Settlement Agreement 
executed between the parties to which they shall remain bound. 
 
4. 
Let a decree-sheet be drawn up by the Registry.  
 
5. 
The plaintiffs would be entitled to refund of court fee, if any, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:11.04.2023
15:25:22
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:2449 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 & cont. matter

deposited by them. 
 
6. 
Miscellaneous applications do not survive for consideration and 
are disposed of accordingly. 
 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J 
MARCH 29, 2023

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
According to the provided PDF document, "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", the legal proceedings involve a dispute between Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr (Petitioners) and Rishabh Bansal & Anr (Respondents) in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The case is listed as C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 and I.A. 15915/2022, with a Neutral Citation Number of 2023:DHC:2449.

The parties were represented by their respective advocates, Mr. Vishal Patel for the Petitioners and Ms. Akanksha Singh for the Respondents. The matter was heard by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar. 

A settlement agreement was executed on March 14, 2023, under the aegis of the Delhi High Court Mediation and Conciliation Centre. The terms of the settlement were placed on record, with Respondent No. 1/Defendant admitting to certain terms. The judgment (oral) was delivered on March 29, 2023.

The PDF document provides details of the legal proceedings, including the case number, parties, dates, and representation. However, specific facts, arguments, and amounts are not mentioned in the provided section. The settlement agreement and its terms are also not fully disclosed in the given excerpt. The document is a court record, and further details may be available in the complete PDF file, "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf".

tree_structure.title: Facts and Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi heard the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 and cont. matter. The plaintiffs/petitioners, Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr, are the original and registered proprietors of the trademark/label 'SAKARNI' in respect of goods falling in class 19 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. 

The respondent, Rishabh Bansal, acknowledged the proprietary rights of the plaintiffs/petitioners in the trademarks and admitted to their copyright in the artistic features of the packaging pouches and labels. The respondent undertook not to commit any act of infringement or passing off by using the trademark/device SATKARMI/SAKARNI or any other mark/name identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiffs/petitioners' registered trademarks/labels.

The respondent also undertook not to use scripts, fonts, positions, and placement of features, get-ups, lay-outs, combination of colors, and arrangements identical or deceptively similar to the plaintiffs/petitioners' pouches/packaging material. Additionally, the respondent agreed to withdraw the application/registration of the impugned mark/device SATKARMI bearing no. 3564551 in Class 19 within two weeks from the date of execution of the present settlement.

In view of the undertakings by the respondent, the plaintiffs/petitioners agreed to withdraw the rectification petition C.O. (Comm. IPD-TM) No. 752/2022. The settlement was digitally signed by Sunil Singh Negi on 11.04.2023. (Source: Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf, Neutral Citation Number: 2023:DHC:2449)

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary: According to page 2 of the PDF "27. Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", the Respondent no. 1/Defendant acknowledges the proprietary rights of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners in the trademarks 'SAKARNI PLASTER/SAKARNI WALL GUARD/SAKARNI' and their copyright in the artistic features of packaging pouches and labels. The Respondent also admits to the Plaintiffs/Petitioners being prior users of the trademark and undertakes not to commit any act of infringement or passing off by using similar marks or features. The Respondent further undertakes not to reproduce or adapt any of the artistic features of the Plaintiffs/Petitioners' packaging material, constituting infringement of their copyright. The document is dated 11.04.2023, and the case number is C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022. The parties involved are Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr (Petitioners) and Rishabh Bansal & Anr (Respondents).

Rishabh Bansal.pdf", the Respondent no. 1/Defendant, Rishabh Bansal, undertakes to withdraw the application/registration of the impugned mark "SATKARMI" and not file any similar applications in the future. The Respondent also agrees to recall marketing materials, destroy blocks and dies with the impugned mark, and not apply for registration of any trade mark/trade name deceptively similar to the Plaintiff's "SAKARNI" mark. The case details are C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 and Neutral Citation Number: 2023:DHC:2449.

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary: According to page 4 of the PDF "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", the parties have reached a settlement agreement. The Respondent no. 1/Defendant has no objection to a decree of perpetual injunction in favor of the plaintiffs. The parties confirm that they have gone through the terms and conditions of the settlement and agree to abide by them. They also understand that breach of the terms and conditions may invite lawful action for contempt of court. The settlement agreement is binding, and the parties undertake to abide by its terms. The learned counsel for both parties are present and undertake to abide by the terms of settlement. The court disposes of the rectification petition and decrees the suit in terms of the settlement agreement. The PDF is related to the case C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 and C.S.(COMM.) 48/2023, with a neutral citation number of 2023:DHC:2449.
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023:DHC:2449 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 & cont. matter 
Page 4 of 5 
 
herein above provided that such breach/default arises out of the 
act(s) which are directly within the power and control of the 
Respondent no. 1/Defendant; 
 
n.  
The Respondent no. 1/Defendant has no objection if a 
decree of perpetual injunction is passed by this Hon'ble Court in 
favour of the plaintiffs according to the prayer clause of the 
paragraph 32 (a)&(b) of the plaint in CS (Comm.) No. 48 of 2023 
along with terms and conditions of the present settlement. 
 
o.  
The parties have gone through the terms and conditions 
herein and confirm and verify the same to be correct and that they 
put their signatures hereunder without any threat, coercion, 
pressure, or undue influence from any quarter and both sides agree 
to abide by the terms and conditions herein. 
 
p.  
The Parties have gone through this present Settlement 
Agreement and have understood the same and have no objections 
to the present terms and conditions. The parties also understand 
that bleach of the terms and conditions of this Settlement 
Agreement shall invite lawful action for contempt of court against 
them by the other party in the concerned Court 
 
q.  
That the Parties undertake before the Hon'ble Court to 
abide by the terms and conditions set out in the agreement and not 
to dispute the same hereinafter in future. 
 
r.  
The parties agree that they shall appear before the Hon'ble 
court during the hearing to make their statements in terms of the 
present settlement agreement.” 
 
2. 
Learned Counsel are present on behalf of their respective 
parties.  They undertake to abide by the aforesaid terms of settlement. 
 
3. 
As such, nothing survives for adjudication in the suit as well as 
the rectification petition.  Rectification petition stands disposed of and 
the suit stands decreed in terms of the aforesaid Settlement Agreement 
executed between the parties to which they shall remain bound. 
 
4. 
Let a decree-sheet be drawn up by the Registry.  
 
5. 
The plaintiffs would be entitled to refund of court fee, if any, 
Digitally Signed
By:SUNIL SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:11.04.2023
15:25:22
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Decision and Orders
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", a legal proceeding was held in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The case involves petitioners Ashok Kumar Gupta and another (represented by Mr. Vishal Patel, Adv.) and respondents Rishabh Bansal and another (represented by Ms. Akanksha Singh, Adv.). The Neutral Citation Number for this case is 2023:DHC:2449.

The court considered C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 752/2022 and I.A. 15915/2022 (Order XXXIX Rules 1 and 2 of the CPC), as well as C.S.(COMM.) 48/2023 and I.A. 16. The decision was made by Hon'ble Justice C. Hari Shankar on March 29, 2023.

The document mentions that miscellaneous applications do not survive for consideration and are disposed of accordingly. It also mentions that certain amounts were deposited by the parties involved. However, the exact amounts and details of the deposits are not specified in the provided section.

The digitally signed document was verified by Sunil Singh Negi on April 11, 2023. The source of this information is the PDF document "Ashok Kumar Gupta & Anr v. Rishabh Bansal.pdf", which provides the details of the court proceedings and decisions made in the case.
